data.title: AVLV: High-Quality Active Value Play, A Hold
data.description:
Today, I would like to offer the reassessment of the Avantis US Large Cap Value ETF (AVLV), an actively managed vehicle that is all about the value and quality factors in the U.S. large-cap universe, which I first reviewed in February 2023 with a conservative Hold rating.

Am I bullish on AVLV today? To be clear, even though investors' reaction to tech juggernauts' earnings has been mixed for now, it is still complicated to construct a thesis for the immediate shift in the market's narrative, as the case for the interest rates going down is in place, and the AI narrative remains supportive of elevated valuations (even though they are looking increasingly worrisome to me, but as a value investor, I do have a certain bias).

In this regard, I see no justification for switching from the growth & quality factor combination (or just pure growth, for investors with higher tolerance to risk) to value & quality.

In other words, while AVLV does deserve investor attention, chiefly because of the high quality of its portfolio (I will be giving a lot of details on that below in the note), I see no potential in it to outperform the iShares Core S&P 500 ETF (IVV) in the short to medium term.

Basics of The Avantis US Large Cap Value ETF

  • Inception: September 21, 2021
  • AUM: $8.397 billion, as of October 30
  • Investment Advisor: American Century Investment Management, Inc.
  • Expense Ratio: 0.15%
  • 3-Year Annualized Total Return (October 2022–September 2025): 19.7% vs. 16.71% of the iShares Russell 1000 Value ETF (IWD) and 24.9% of IVV

AVLV Strategy: Active, Quality-, Value-Centered

As we know from the Avantis website, AVLV "seeks long-term capital appreciation," is managed actively, and is benchmarked against the Russell 1000 Value Index. The latter fact is the reason why I will be comparing AVLV's factor mix to that of IWD (a mild spoiler as usual: AVLV is considerably stronger in nearly all aspects).

What companies does AVLV favor? As explained in the summary prospectus:

The fund seeks to achieve higher expected returns by selecting securities of companies with higher profitability and value characteristics, as well as smaller market capitalizations relative to others within the fund's large cap investment universe.

There are two key metrics (but there are others) that are considered when deciding whether a company is cheap enough and has appealing profitability:

The portfolio managers define “value characteristics” mainly as adjusted book/price ratio (though other price to fundamental ratios may be considered). The portfolio managers define “profitability” mainly as adjusted cash from operations to book value ratio (though other ratios may be considered).

In the stock selection process, other parameters are taken into account as well, including free float, liquidity, past performance, etc.

Does AVLV's turnover match its active approach? I would say that at 5%, it clearly does not, indicating that the portfolio sees nearly no changes, at least during "the most recent fiscal year" as of the most recent summary prospectus (as of January 1, 2025).

Just for context, IWD's turnover is 3x higher at 15%, and this is the fund tracking an index, not actively managed.

AVLV Performance

Since its inception in September 2021, AVLV has delivered quite a robust performance, as it has beaten IWD and the Invesco S&P 500® Pure Value ETF (RPV), which I believe was secured by the quality ingredient of its strategy.

Unfortunately, even though in 2022 it did much better than the growth-heavy IVV (a 5.53% decline vs. IVV's 18.16% decline), it has still significantly underperformed this ETF and, sadly, the iShares S&P 500 Value ETF (IVE).

Looking at the annualized returns and the group of risk metrics I usually assess when comparing ETFs, we see that over October 2021–September 2025, AVLV's CAGR was one of the strongest, plus the maximum drawdown was one of the most comfortable.

On the negative side, its downside capture ratio was 101.71% (indicating that when IVV was struggling, it performed even weaker), the worst result in the group, and quite a disappointment for a value strategy with a quality ingredient.

Another period I would like to focus on is March 2022–September 2025. The reason here is that I believe the Capital Group Dividend Value ETF (CGDV), perhaps one of the best value ETFs in the market, which I upgraded to a Buy in August 2024 (and I am still bullish on the name), should be added to the peer group. Here, it also makes sense to include the JPMorgan Active Value ETF (JAVA), which was incepted in October 2021.

  • Here, CGDV is the champion, with the highest CAGR and the strongest risk-adjusted returns (the Sharpe and Sortino ratios), as well as the lowest downside capture ratio.
  • AVLV has the third-largest CAGR and the fourth-largest Sharpe ratio. Its downside capture ratio was again quite disappointing at 107.67%

AVLV vs. Large Value ETFs

My calculations show that compared to the Large Value ETF subclass, AVLV has delivered rather robust returns for the periods from one month to three years, well in excess of the median levels, only with the YTD result being rather soft.

Parameter AVLV Median for the Large Value subclass
1M Price Return 0.17% -0.39%
6M Price Return 15.81% 12.00%
YTD Price Return 8.40% 10.01%
1Y Price Return 8.97% 7.74%
3Y Price Return 43.90% 37.42%
3Y Total Return 51.70% 45.69%

Calculated by the author using data from Seeking Alpha as of October 31

AVLV Portfolio: Multiple Advantages Over IWD

As of October 29, there were 263 common stocks in the AVLV portfolio, mostly representing consumer discretionary and industrials sectors. Apple Inc. (AAPL) is the key name in this basket, with a 3.66% weight.

Not only AAPL but also four other trillion-dollar names (in the S&P 500, there are nine such companies as of writing this article) qualified for this portfolio, including Alphabet Inc. (GOOG) (GOOGL), Amazon.com, Inc. (AMZN), Meta Platforms Inc. (META), and NVIDIA Corporation (NVDA), with a combined weight of 16.17%. The presence of NVDA in a value factor-oriented portfolio is rather surprising, to be honest.

Most of AVLV's holdings can be found in the IWD portfolio as well, though the above-mentioned NVDA has not qualified for it.

Parameter Weight in AVLV Weight in IWD
Companies present in both AVLV and IWD portfolios 80.97% 31.88%

Calculated by the author using data from the ETFs

However, in IWD, these names account for less than 32% of the net assets, so meaningful differences in factor exposures between the Russell 1000 Value ETF and AVLV, which I will address shortly, are anything but a surprise.

AVLV Sectors

Compared to IWD, and I believe that more likely owing to the quality component of the strategy, AVLV is overweight in five sectors, key among them being consumer discretionary.

At the same time, it is underweight in six, with health care being the main one.

AVLV vs. IWD: Factor Exposures

I would say that the table below quite vividly illustrates that AVLV is significantly stronger than IWD in nearly every aspect.

  • Despite having a 1.7x larger weighted average market cap, the AVLV portfolio has considerably stronger value characteristics than those of IWD, as illustrated by the WA adjusted earnings yield, Price/Sales, EV/EBITDA, and its allocation to stocks with a B- Quant Valuation rating or higher.
  • Quality is where it is also ahead, and considerably so, with over 92% allocated to companies with a B- Quant Profitability rating or higher. Its capital efficiency indicators (for instance, Return on Assets) are meaningfully stronger than IWD's as well.
  • Surprisingly, it even has advantages on the growth front, including a 16.32% WA forward EPS growth rate.
  • Its allocations to stocks exhibiting strong momentum characteristics (a B- Quant Momentum grade or higher) and sporting an appealing EPS Revisions grade are both higher than those of IWD.

Final Thoughts

To conclude, AVLV offers a potent active value & quality strategy, robust enough to beat a few actively and passively managed peers like JAVA and RPV. Regarding factors, it is stronger than IWD in every single aspect I assessed above (some investors might dislike it for higher weighted average beta coefficients though). However, it does have a few disadvantages, chief among them being its inability to beat IVV and CGDV, as well as a quite uncomfortable downside capture ratio. So I believe a Hold rating is the one I should maintain today.

data.title: WTI Price Forecast: Crude To End Week In The Red After Tuesday's Sell-Off
data.description:
By Christian Norman

Currently trading at $61.19 per barrel, crude looks set to end this week’s trading in the red. Unable to pare losses made during Tuesday’s sell-off, where crude pricing fell around 2.23%, WTI trades 0.90% higher in today’s session and, crucially, remains above the key psychological level of $60.

What’s next for crude oil?

WTI Crude (West Texas Intermediate): The glut narrative

Doesn’t sound very nice, does it? While a rising dollar certainly doesn’t help oil pricing, the current rhetoric within crude markets remains unchanged from previous coverage: oversupply.

With that said, and while I’m hesitant to say the winds of change are fully blowing, I’d be comfortable in saying that a faint breeze is currently blowing across the oil markets, owing to some recent developments.

Let’s discuss.

WTI Crude (West Texas Intermediate): Fundamental Analysis 31/10/2025

Rumours of United States military action in Venezuela

To start with a positive for oil pricing, today’s rally comes after reports that the United States would be performing some kind of military action in Venezuela, a founding member of OPEC.

Nineteenth by volume of crude production in 2024, the headlines offer a supply-side tail risk to oil pricing, which the markets have received as positive for crude pricing.

While Trump and his administration have consistently accused Venezuela and its government of allowing the export of illegal narcotics into the United States, he spoke earlier today to deny any involvement.

Reporter: "There are reports that you are considering strikes within Venezuela. Is that true? Has any decision been made on that?"DJT: "No, it's not true"

Times News, 31/10/2025

It would seem, however, that markets are less convinced, especially with the increased US military presence in the Caribbean Ocean in recent weeks. As can be expected, developments such as these threaten global oil supply, which boosts pricing - as seen in today’s session.

The effectiveness of US sanctions on Russian crude exports now in question

Used primarily as a bargaining tool to encourage Putin to return to the negotiating table regarding the Russia-Ukraine conflict, markets are seriously questioning the effectiveness of recent sanctions.

While predictably, the Kremlin made comments shortly after the announcement to suggest that the domestic Russian oil industry would be unaffected by new American sanctions, markets are now taking these comments more seriously.

This goes double for Vladimir Putin, who went on record to say he would not be “cowed” by other nations into making concessions about Ukraine, while simultaneously boasting about the success of new nuclear technology.

While it is understandable that Trump wants to target Russian fossil fuels, with the three largest companies by market cap in Russia, Lukoil (OTC:LUKOY), Rosneft (OTC:RNFTF), and Gazprom (OTCPK:GZPFY), all being energy corporations, it will take more supply-side risk to secure higher pricing for WTI, which is on pace for its worst yearly performance since 2020.

As expected, the level of risk premium priced into WTI markets has reduced significantly this week, not only due to the above, but also because of the market’s inherent nature: sudden news events often cause the markets to overreact.

OPEC+ agrees on modest December output increase

Earlier in your reading, you may recall that I mentioned a potential shift in the status quo for crude, with the latest news from OPEC+ being what I was referring to.

With a meeting due this coming Sunday, the group leans towards a modest increase in output throughout December of 137,000 barrels, meeting the same target as September and October.

Of course, an increase in supply with demand unchanged is inherently oil price negative, but considering OPEC has opted for a modest increase in production three months consecutively, markets are beginning to read between the lines:

OPEC+ is becoming increasingly comfortable with the global oil supply

If nothing else, this begins to limit the downside potential of crude, with current supply levels unlikely to be hiked significantly going forward.

WTI Crude (West Texas Intermediate): Technical Analysis 31/10/2025

WTI (WTICOUSD): Daily (D1) chart analysis:

By a few technical metrics, including the 10-period SSL channel, there is evidence of some bullish fight in the market, but the overarching trend remains bearish.

If the second price target can be achieved, however, this paves the way for further bullish momentum, especially considering the limited downside from the OPEC+ side of things.

To the downside, support can be found at the 20-period moving average and the key psychological level of $60. If the latter is to be breached, we can expect a sharp sell-off towards the lows made in mid-October.

Price targets and support/resistance levels:

  • Price target #1: Previous support turned resistance - $62.56
  • Price target #2: $63.56-61.8% Fib
  • Support #1: $60.18 - 20-period SMA
  • Support #2: $60.00 - Key psychological level

Original Post

Editor's Note: This article discusses one or more securities that do not trade on a major U.S. exchange. Please be aware of the risks associated with these stocks.

data.title: Chicago PMI Contracts For 23rd Consecutive Month
data.description:
By Jennifer Nash

The Chicago Purchasing Managers’ Index (Chicago Business Barometer) rose more than expected in October, increasing 3.2 points to 43.8. This reading came in above the projected 42.3. Despite the improvement, the index still came in below 50, which marks the 23rd consecutive month of contraction for regional business activity.

Background on Chicago PMI

The Chicago PMI assesses the business conditions and the economic health of the manufacturing sector in the Chicago region. A value above 50.0 indicates expanding manufacturing activity, while a value below 50.0 indicates contracting manufacturing activity.

Looking at its historical performance, the current level of 43.8 is lower than where the index stood at the start of 6 of the 7 recessions since its inception. This suggests that such weak readings have often preceded broader economic downturns.

A Closer Look Since 2000

Examining data since 2000, the index has undergone fluctuations, often aligning with broader economic cycles. Given its persistent weakness, the current level reinforces concerns about ongoing softness in the manufacturing sector.

Chicago PMI vs. ISM Manufacturing Index

Let's compare the Chicago PMI with the more popular national ISM manufacturing index. Over the 666 months of available data, the Chicago PMI has been higher 69% of the time. However, despite this frequent outperformance, its historical average of 54.3 is only slightly higher than the ISM’s 52.4.

It's clear the two indices tend to move together; however, it’s important to note that the ISM Manufacturing Index is reported with a one-month lag.

Original Post

Editor's Note: The summary bullets for this article were chosen by Seeking Alpha editors.

data.title: Veolia Environnement: Still One Of The Best Plays In Water/Recycling Going Into Q3
data.description:
There's a general dearth of investment opportunities that are undervalued at this particular time. The general overvalued state of the market at this time is something that worries me. What do I mean by "general overvalued state of the market"?

Sometimes pictures speak louder than words - and this is, in my view, one of those times. We can look at SPDR® S&P 500 ETF Trust (SPY).

This doesn't mean that a correction has to come now, or even in the near term. But based on historical metrics, it suggests that a correction is coming - even if we don't know the exact timing.

This potential for a correction has me essentially "not investing" at this time, except where I can see very clear upsides based on low valuations, in safe companies that will withstand "any" downturn, and where I have a long-term conviction. Such companies obviously come in many different shapes. Some are REITs, some are companies such as utilities, and some might be pharma companies. In this article, a follow-up to this particular piece from about six months back, I am going to update my thesis on Veolia Environnement SA (OTCPK:VEOEY, Euronext Paris: VIE). Veolia is what I would consider an "environment" company. That doesn't mean renewables, but instead things like recycling, wastewater, water, and the like. If you follow my work, you know that I love these sorts of companies for the combination of regulatory safety, growth potential, and the fundamental characteristics they offer.

In this article, I will update my thesis on the company, which, I believe, is far more attractive than last time I covered it, using the Q2 '25/Half-year results, and a forecast for Q3 '25, which are set to be released in less than 4 weeks (currently estimated for November 6th).

Let's see what we have here.

Veolia: Upside Is Here, Fundamentals Are Solid, Growth Is likely - I See Few Downsides

Veolia is one of those companies where I honestly see very few long-term, short-term, or medium-term downsides.

Why is that?

A combination of factors. Let's go through them, with examples for each.

First off, fundamentals. The company is simply very appealing. BBB credit means the company is IG-rated, and despite this, it has a close to 5% yield, which, for a French multi-utility with these sorts of basics, is very solid. The company has been able to grow EPS in double digits since COVID-19, and current forecasts consider it likely for this growth to continue. While at times volatile, as history suggests, the past few years have seen the company really consolidate around its core strengths, providing potential growth.

This potential growth and potential can be seen in things like the Suez M&A, expected by me and other analysts to be very value-accretive to the companies in the near term. This is despite the price paid, which, according to some, was too high.

I'm also not the only one to consider 2025-2027E results to be very conservative - this is one of those companies where I expect significantly better results than even the market does.

Even if the company's target markets were to slow down, the company has ample room for operational efficiencies, as evidenced by both the financial and management. But perhaps most importantly, Veolia has removed much of its cyclical exposure over the past two decades - another advantage. Furthermore, due to the relatively high inflation rate we've been having, cost savings rates have been seeing a higher retention rate - and the economic slowdown in Europe is turning around a bit, resulting in some upside for the company here.

2Q25/1H25 results were solid and do not, to my mind, reflect the current valuation of the company. This is because revenue continues to grow even without energy price adjustments, at over 3.5%, and EBITDA is up over 5%, EBIT up over 8%, and net income up over 12.4% excluding the SADE disposal back in -24.

The company's net debt is now fully under control at around €20B, following some investments, and as of Q2 '25, the 2025E guidance is intact.

As you can see above, the company is a play on water, waste, and heating. Three of the basic building blocks of our modern society. If they also had electricity generation to any significant degree and managed to make it work within the business model, it would be almost ridiculously solid. But the company, instead, is focusing on "boosters," which are specialized forms of its current operations, like Bioenergy, Hazardous waste, and Water tech. Veolia is one of the most significant players in hazardous waste in certain geographies, and the company's significant push into the Middle East is one of the core reasons I remain so positive about the company here.

The company's synergy improvements over time have delivered over €150M worth of gains, with €482M post-Suez synergy gains, which is entirely in line with the year-end 2025E target of €530M. The company will, as I see it, deliver exactly or close to what it promised.

These things matter.

Despite what can be described accurately as a muted performance since my last article, I would go ahead and say that there are very few reasons to be so conservative about the company. Well, aside from political risks in France, where much of the legacy operations are located, there is very little operational risk at the very least. And the more the company actually moves outside of its legacy geography and becomes international, the more resilient it's likely to be.

Veolia has not been assigned a premium by the market since late 2021. Since then, and the crash back in mid-2021/2022, it's been discounted at various rates. Today it trades below 13.2x, which, given what the company does, is fairly interesting.

I am much more positive about the company than I was even just a year ago. I consider it to have a moat, which it did not have in 2023-2024 (stabilization of municipal legacy water operations, following the fallout of municipal water cancellations and annulments in -15). The renewal rates for Veolia's contracts in France are also above 90%, highlighting just how entrenched this company is.

I believe that any valuation that puts this company below 13-14x P/E severely underestimates this company's potential - and that's with no growth, as opposed to the growth that's being forecasted here.

For Q3 '25, I expect the company to continue alongside the performance to deliver an EPS growth of about 5% this year, with a growing EPS growth into 2026 and 2027E. I expect an EPS moving from €2.13/share this year to well over €2.6/share in 2 years. Even on the basis of just a conservative valuation, this would imply a significant upside here. The reason the company is likely to outperform in both Q3 '25 and 2025 is continued cost synergies, savings, and new contracts. I believe a combination of new business coupled with significant growth in key segments, like Hazardous waste, will deliver the 6-8% growth in earnings in 2026 and 2027, alongside better savings. For my assumptions, I use about a 6% WACC in my calculations, which I believe to be fair for this business.

Valuation For Veolia: Upside Intact, More Than 15% Annualized, Is Easy To See

At less than 13.2x P/E, the company is what I would consider undervalued. We have not reached the bottom we saw in 2024, but I'm not sure we're going down that far.

The upside, even just to a 15x P/E, is almost 20% per year here, making it a very solid investment choice.

And I don't forecast at 15x P/E. As I said in previous articles, my estimate for the fair value of Veolia is above 18-19x P/E, which implies a fair value level of €50/share. And even that is not very exuberant - because the company's 20-year average suggests a P/E of over 22x, implying a fair value of over €65/share. I'm not going that high - I'm "happy" at 18-19x. My €50/share fair value suggests that you can buy this company in 2027 below €42/share, and this year at about €37/share or below. That was part of the rationale for my €36.5 PT, which I at this time also retain from my previous article.

Over time, I fully expect my investment here to generate well over a 70-80% RoR, even though this will likely take time. I expect the company's CapEx to "peak out" at about €3.8B per year until 2029 or so, and this excludes the buyout of minorities in one of the company's operations back in June of this year, in line with guidance. Taking this into consideration also doesn't change my thesis in a significant way.

The only reason that's holding me back from going even higher with my expectations here is the fact that the company's regulated municipal operations, as the name suggests, regulators will prevent Veolia from earning returns in excess of expectations. Much of the company's earnings still come from regulated businesses. This is not a bad thing. But in my view, it puts a cap on what's possible for Veolia.

I view Veolia as a "BUY" with a €36.5/share PT here.

Alternatives I would consider in the same sector would be only one - American Water Works (AWK) (and that one isn't even that close in operations to this one, beyond water). However, AWK is tricky here because at a conservative valuation, the company doesn't offer my hurdle in the same way that Veolia does.

For that reason, I consider Veolia to be the "choice cut" in this sector.

Risks are as follows.

Risks & Considerations

Risks to the company are primarily related to French municipal trends and regulations. The events in -09 highlight the political risks in France, when annulment of contracts until 2015 in the water space was announced - and it's not impossible that such an event may happen again (though given current trends, I do consider it on the unlikely side).

Aside from this, it's all about the impact of savings, how much savings and efficiency can bring to the table, next to the company's other improvements. There's an open question here, but I would point to what the company has been able to do previously.

Aside from that, I do not see any noteworthy risks to the company, and therefore consider the company a Buy with the following thesis.

Thesis

Veolia is a great business in several great fields, and this upside has materialized since the full results for 2025 H1. They have some excellent moats, a solid history, and good future prospects. The Suez M&A only strengthened the company's next few years, and whatever downsides exist and uncertainties are there, I believe they're outweighed by the upside potential in this stock, further enhanced by more savings and efficiencies.

There are downsides and risks, but these, at this valuation of below 14x, are relatively small. A company such as this, with these sorts of operations, at this sort of price, is precisely the sort of investment you may want to make - at least it's the sort of investment that I, personally, want to go "deeper" in.

This upside can even go up to 15-35% if we allow for a premium valuation or even higher, historically accurate EPS growth (which I am open to), valuing the company at 18-19x P/E. My official PT is €36.5/share for October/November 2025, and I'm at a Buy at this time.

Here are my criteria and how the company fulfills them (italicized).

  • This company is overall qualitative.
  • This company is fundamentally safe/conservative & well-run.
  • This company pays a well-covered dividend.
  • This company is currently cheap.
  • This company has a realistic upside based on earnings growth or multiple expansion/reversion.

The company fulfills 3 out of 3 quality indicators, and 1 out of 2 valuation indicators. That means 4/5 "stars" here, which is enough for an attractive thesis for the company. Based on this, and a valuation target of €36.5/share where I see a risk/reward-adjusted upside that's attractive enough for me. I give the company a Buy rating as of October/November 2025.

Editor's Note: This article discusses one or more securities that do not trade on a major U.S. exchange. Please be aware of the risks associated with these stocks.

data.title: Amazon's Future Is Autonomous
data.description:
Since my last Amazon.com, Inc. (AMZN) analysis, the stock has gained 16% in price, a price return that has been particularly bolstered by strong Q3 earnings. In my prior analysis I analyzed the company's margin optimization, including operational efficiencies and Q2 earnings. My analysis was focused more on macro financials and sentiment considerations amid broad-based operational analysis. In this assessment, I'm delving into the company's autonomous strategy, a topic widely circulating in the press right now.

Preface: Q3

Before we begin on exploring the macro autonomy case for Amazon, the company just posted Q3 earnings, so I'll get you up to speed on that quickly here. If you're not interested in short-term earnings, feel free to skip to the next section below.

In Q3, net sales were up by +13% year-over-year, and service revenue significantly outpaced product revenue in growth (+16% versus +9.6%), with services offering a structurally more profitable mix. While the company's operating income was flat year-over-year, two charges hit which were non-recurring ($2.5B related to an FTC legal settlement, and ~$1.8B of severance). Without those charges, operating margin would have been ~12% versus ~11% a year ago.

The AI/data-center build-out is still consuming cash at a remarkable rate. As of Q3, Amazon's TTM operating cash flow was $130.7B (up 16% year-over-year), but free cash flow fell to $14.8B because TTM purchases of PP&E were $115.9B.

The headline Q4 guide was for net sales of between +10% and +13% year-over-year, with modestly higher margins into peak season.

Overall, it was a strong quarter, marked by real structural investment trends that are outweighed by profitability-focused growth and long-term moat effects being established. All of this is well understood by the market, which is why shares rallied 14% post-release.

Amazon Is Structurally Aligned With America's Growth Imperative

We've already established in my last analysis that Amazon's next alpha phase is operating-leverage led. Any fears about Amazon's automation horizon appear misguided to me, given that there is no logical reality whereby the U.S. does not compete for macroeconomic leadership through bolstered capital market growth. This can only be achieved through the reduction in federal debt-to-GDP by boosting GDP growth. Though it may be decades before work becomes "optional," the workforce will likely trend away from human labor toward oversight of autonomous systems in the next 10 years (this is common sense, if you see the current trends in AI adoption, growth, and automated workflows already permeating).

That means that at first, Amazon's workforce will probably slow in growth, but eventually, yes, I see no reason why the workforce will not be "cut." This might see pushback from regulatory agencies, but those agencies would illogically be working against the macroeconomic health of free world nations by stunting GDP growth by reducing the capital efficiencies of low-cost-to-serve autonomous behemoths, like Amazon.

Specifically, autonomy reduces hires per unit of volume, which reduces exposure to wage inflation and peak-season hiring spikes. Amazon's filings actually still show increasing logistics costs, but they are being partially offset by network efficiencies, so labor minutes per unit are falling without excessive job cuts. This reflects a staggered approach to efficiency optimization as AI capabilities ramp up and before any speculative government-backed UBI supports demand even amid lower employment rates.

Even in the short term, the notion of UBI may not be as critical as we assume if pricing reduces and demand increases as forms of "optional" labor dominate the macro free market; i.e., the notion of "socialism amid autonomy" could be defunct. Right now, as automation makes the same-/next-day network more efficient and reduces the cost to serve per unit, small but persistent price cuts will transfer to the shopper (including time). That smooths volatility in discretionary spending and raises baseline demand, particularly in repeatable, low-ASP categories where shipping fees previously made financial returns look weak.

Margins Rise As Prices Fall And Shares Keep Compounding

We're really looking at two effects here on the company's financial positioning; the first is expanded gross margin, and the second is reduced prices for consumers. The second-order effect should be gradually increasing demand, allowing for the company to be considered a "growth stock" for decades to come if executed properly. This is rare—usually companies at maturity, like Amazon, transform into stalwarts and focus on operational efficiencies moderately to maintain average capital appreciation amid a saturated market. Amazon is in a unique position where it can incrementally improve margins and slash product and shipping prices to create an EPS-revenue growth flywheel; it looks like this:

Gross margin expansion raises EPS –> lower prices and delivery friction lift revenue volume –> volume growth compounds operating leverage –> EPS growth over revenue growth while revenue growth stays resilient –> reinvestment sustains the flywheel for decades.

This is the primary reason why investing in Amazon right now is wise. You're investing in a growth flywheel that is optimized for durability amid the disruption from autonomous technology. Sentiment for the stock is elevated, but deservedly so. The monthly-intervals price chart shows the stock heavily above the 50-month MA, but this is typical for Amazon across the past 15 years. You get what you pay for, and Amazon, by all means of fundamental assessment, offers a fair valuation with resilient market-leading growth strengthened by a resilient moat.

The company's forward PEG non-GAAP ratio is only about 10% higher than the sector, which reflects a moderate premium but indicates that the market is probably correctly bullish on the fact that consensus growth estimates are a little too low.

I consider it important at this juncture to consider an allocation in Amazon based on future growth optionality that is implicit in the current macro trends. That is, as automated machinery and intelligent software scale, Amazon is a key beneficiary across both its physical and digital infrastructure stack. This vertically integrated model bolsters the likelihood that Amazon will outperform the analyst consensus. However, we also should recognize that Amazon has never significantly outperformed the consensus price targets in the past five years, meaning that achieving a 20%+ stock price CAGR over the long term is less likely than if Amazon stock was undervalued by Wall Street (it's not).

Labor Optics, Deflation, And Macro Elasticity

Unfortunately, even slower hiring per unit of volume can be portrayed politically as job destruction; the NLRB and state labor boards have already scrutinized Amazon's warehouse practices, and a rapid pivot to robotics could reignite union and legislative pressure.

Looking further out, Amazon can't indefinitely offset macro softness through price cuts without eroding unit economics, so if discretionary income compresses in phases, Amazon's earnings power could also face volatility. This is why I believe management will be much more focused on macroeconomic analysis in the decade ahead to time price decreases (and increases) amid changing socioeconomics due to smaller big enterprise workforces softening demand in cycles unless prices correspondingly collapse.

My above thesis also assumes rising affordability and optional labor sustain demand, but if political systems fail to backfill displaced income or if consumer psychology shifts toward savings, volume expansion could undershoot expectations. Also, in the bear case, systematic price deflation from automation could suppress nominal revenue growth even as EPS rises—to put it another way, staging or tempering the fundamental implications of autonomy may equate to a beast too difficult to tame.

Conclusion: Buy

I'm bullish on Amazon, but I think expectations need to be tempered. This is not a 3x the market stock; it's 2x the market at a push, and more like 50% greater returns than the S&P 500 (SP500) in the base case. That's still a decent return, but it isn't the 30–50% annual return one would seek if scrutinizing the market for the highest growth compounders.

In my opinion, Amazon has a place in portfolios as ballast, aka defensive growth, which sounds contradictory given management's aggressive autonomy stance. However, the company is simply too saturated in its market for technological mechanics to make this an elite pick in terms of absolute returns. Amazon stock is elite in resiliency, and was once elite for its stock price returns, but now, the company has morphed into a mechanism for growth-portfolio security.

data.title: Federal Signal: Mixed Signals For Investors
data.description:
Over the summer I concluded that Federal Signal (FSS) was firing on all cylinders, driven by a combination of strong organic growth, accretive M&A efforts, and prudent capital allocation.

Blow-out earnings and ambitious long-term margins caused shares to jump by the end of July, and while the underlying achievements were impressive, I was cautious to chase the shares amidst higher expectations.

By now shares have fallen back to the $115 mark as elevated expectations came down a bit amidst softer third-quarter orders, while a textbook M&A effort was announced.

Specialty Equipment Maker Becomes More Special

Federal Signal was founded in the very early part of the 20th century and over time has grown to become an all-round designer, manufacturer, and supplier of specialty equipment to a wide range of customers. This includes an oversized share of municipal and governmental clients as well as other commercial clients.

By now the company employs about 5,000 workers who produce a wide range of specialty equipment, with this lineup expanding after more than a dozen acquisitions over the past decade. This, and organic growth, made that sales tripled to $2 billion, with operating margins increasing to 15% of sales, while the company actually managed to reduce the share count in a small fashion.

The vast majority of this equipment is related to the environmental solutions group, making up about 80% of sales. This includes products like vacuum trucks, sweepers, road markers, dump trucks, etc. The remainder of sales is largely comprised of safety and security products, in itself consisting of signaling and warning systems, among others.

Publicly funded clients make up half of sales, with the remainder largely coming from industrial clients, notably oil and gas, utility, and other clients. One final comment about the business: Long having been somewhat of a stagnant business, the company and its performance really came to life over the past decade, certainly in more recent years.

About Those Valuations

After posting an impressive 20% revenue growth in 2023, with growth largely driven by organic sales, momentum continued last year, albeit in a slightly smaller fashion. Revenues rose by a more modest 8% to $1.86 billion, although the backlog actually was down 3% on the year before at $1 billion.

However, adjusted earnings rose by 29% to $3.34 per share, as the company clearly was seeing strong margin gains given the percentage differential in growth. Moreover, momentum was only set to continue in 2025, in part aided by a $78 million deal to acquire the owner of Hog Technologies. The company initially guided for sales to advance to $2.02-$2.10 billion, with earnings seen moving up further towards $3.60-$3.90 per share.

Trading around the $100 mark in the spring, shares were not necessarily very cheap given the outlook, but a blowout quarter arrived in July when second-quarter sales were reported up 15%. Even better, the backlog rose to $1.08 billion following a very strong order intake, with full-year sales seen around $2.10 billion and earnings seen at a midpoint of $4 per share.

Management furthermore raised its long-term margin targets, as all this and a leverage ratio of just 0.5 times made investors upbeat. However, based on this momentum seen already, earnings around $4 per share made that share trade at a low thirty times earnings multiples already. Hence, momentum in the shares did not automatically create a compelling risk-reward, in my view.

Some Reality Kicks In

After shares traded around the $130 mark recently, shares have sold off about 10% to $115 per share in the wake of the release of the third quarter results.

In September, Federal Signal announced the purchase of Scranton Manufacturing Company, a US-based designer and manufacturer of refuse collection vehicles. The purchase price of $396 million furthermore excludes a $30 million transaction sum for the real estate of the property and a potential earn-out of $54 million, based on the performance in the coming two years. On the flip side, the net present value of tax benefits is pegged at $60 million.

Factoring in these tax benefits, the company claims an 11 times current EBITDA multiple being paid, suggesting that Scranton will add some $30 million in synergies. That multiple is seen dropping to 7 times by 2028, suggesting a $48 million EBITDA contribution that year, driven by realization of synergies. This matches the $15-$20 million synergy estimate provided, which by 2028 should boost earnings by $0.40-$0.45 per share.

Third-quarter sales rose by 17% to $555 million, with organic growth reported at a solid 11%. However, orders rose by just 10% to $467 million, pushing the backlog down to just below the billion mark, being somewhat of a worrying factor. Full-year sales are now seen around $2.12 billion, with adjusted earnings seen at a midpoint of $4.13 per share, but the softer orders likely make investors cautious.

Net debt was down to $159 million, but this will jump to $585 million pro forma for the Scranton deal (ex earnout). That's no worry with adjusted EBITDA trending around $450 million here if we annualize the third quarter performance, for a leverage ratio just over 1 times.

What Now?

In between the summer and today, we have seen some share price stagnation and, on a net basis, a slightly lower share price. By now, a low thirty times earnings multiple has come down to 27–28 times, while the company will see a small impetus from higher earnings and M&A, the latter looking just fine according to the playbook of Federal Signal here.

Hence, appeal is on the increase, but that does not necessarily make that appeal surfacing just yet, as orders have been a bit soft, with the backlog being pretty stable in dollar terms. However, in relation to sales, the backlog is shrinking quite a bit in terms of how many months of backlog are seen in relation to revenues.

That and higher expectations likely set the stock up for a potential disappointment, and despite the correction, I'm still erring a bit cautious here. For appeal to be found, I'm looking to get involved at levels around the $100 mark, as my admiration of Federal Signal has only grown over time.

data.title: BKGI: This Infrastructure Fund Could Be A Good Option For Income
data.description:
The Bny Mellon Global Infrastructure Income ETF (BKGI) is an exchange-traded fund that aims to provide its investors with a fairly high yield and respectable overall total return. The fund’s website states:

The fund seeks long-term total return, and also targets, but does not guarantee, an annualized gross forward-looking 12-month yield of 6% or more for its portfolio.

A 6% yield is a bit below the 7% that we prefer to target here at Energy Profits in Dividends, but it is still more than most midstream corporations deliver. For example, consider the following midstream energy corporations:

Company Name

Current Yield

The Williams Companies (WMB)

3.47%

Pembina Pipeline (PBA)

5.40%

Kinder Morgan (KMI)

4.49%

Targa Resources (TRGP)

2.64%

DT Midstream (DTM)

2.99%

Antero Midstream (AM)

5.15%

Enbridge (ENB)

5.75%

ONEOK (OKE)

6.18%

With the exception of ONEOK, which has seen its share price beaten down considerably since the start of this year, none of these companies managed to deliver a yield in excess of 6% and none of them managed to beat our targeted 7% yield. There are still some master limited partnerships that can deliver a 7% or higher yield, but the overall strength of the market and the strong performance of many midstream corporations over the past few years have made it very difficult to even manage to achieve a 6% yield. Thus, BKGI’s targeted yield looks fairly attractive in the current market environment.

With that said, the fund does not appear to be hitting its 6% yield target. As of September 30, 2025, the fund’s website claims that it has an annualized yield of 5.39%:

However, if we look at the distributions that the fund has paid out over the past twelve months, we see this:

Ex Date

Record Date

Payable Date

Amount

10/01/2025

10/01/2025

10/06/2025

$0.3019

07/01/2025

07/01/2025

07/07/2025

$0.4769

04/01/2025

04/01/2025

04/04/2025

$0.0659

12/27/2024

12/27/2024

01/02/2025

$0.4129

This fund pays a quarterly distribution, so the above four distributions are the only ones that it has paid out in the past year. The total of these four numbers is $1.2576 per share, which is a 4.26% yield at the current share price of $39.50 each.

I am not sure how the fund’s management is calculating the 5.39% distribution yield that it is advertising on its website. The largest distribution that the fund paid out over the past twelve months was $0.4769 per share, which annualizes to $1.9076 per share. That would only be a 4.83% yield at the current share price. Thus, I cannot see any supporting evidence for the fund’s claim on the website. Based on the distributions that this fund has paid out over the past year, the yield appears to be somewhere between 4% and 5%.

This is still decent, especially given that the richly valued market has made it increasingly difficult to find anything with a respectable yield, but given that various sources seem to differ on what this fund’s yield actually is, we should keep the above discussion in mind and not get too excited when a source shows it to have a remarkably high yield.

About The BNY Mellon Global Infrastructure ETF

The website for the BNY Mellon Global Infrastructure Income ETF states that it has the primary objective of providing its investors with a high level of long-term total return, which makes sense considering that this fund invests in common equities. The fund’s prospectus makes this quite clear, as it states:

The fund normally invests at least 80% of its net assets in securities issued by dividend-paying infrastructure companies.

The fund seems to take something of a broad approach with its definition of an infrastructure company. Most investors in other infrastructure funds expect that it will include things such as midstream energy, both electric and natural gas utilities, and things such as railroads and toll roads. Basically, these are companies that are largely taken for granted and frequently ignored by market analysts, but at the same time modern life would not actually be possible without them. BKGI includes those traditional infrastructure companies, but it also states that it includes things like communications services, health care, and real estate. It can be somewhat difficult to understand how such companies can be considered infrastructure firms, although a good case could be made for a telecommunications company that owns networks of fiber optic cables, considering how critical the Internet has become for modern life.

It is also not too difficult to make a case for a company such as American Tower (AMT), which is a real estate investment trust that owns cellular phone towers, since smartphones and other mobile devices that can access the Internet have also become fairly critical for modern life. However, it is somewhat difficult to make the case for a healthcare company to be included in an infrastructure fund.

With that said, the BNY Mellon Global Infrastructure Income ETF currently appears to be focusing much more on traditional infrastructure plays than on these ancillary segments that the fund’s management seems to think are infrastructure companies. As we can see here, more than half of the fund is currently invested in utility companies, and another 20.21% is invested in energy infrastructure:

Overall, this puts the fund’s allocation to utilities and midstream energy at 76.89%, which when combined with the allocations to industrial infrastructure (such as railroads) and the 6.68% weighting towards telecommunications, has this looking very much like the traditional infrastructure funds that we are largely familiar with. After all, we have discussed other infrastructure funds, such as the Cohen & Steers Infrastructure Fund (UTF), before in this service.

Unlike a closed-end fund that distributes its realized gains to investors, BKGI appears to be attempting to fully cover its distributions solely through the dividends that it receives from the companies that are included in its portfolio. Take a look at the distribution history that is published on the fund’s website:

As we can see, this fund has not distributed any short-term or long-term capital gains since late 2022. It has made a few return of capital distributions, which were probably funded by the fund receiving income from energy partnerships, but otherwise it appears to be investing in dividend-paying infrastructure companies and then distributing the dividends that it receives from these companies to its own investors.

One of the defining characteristics of infrastructure companies is that they tend to have higher distribution yields than most other things in the market. This comes from the fact that the infrastructure sector is a very capital-intensive one, and companies in this industry need to spend a considerable amount of money on infrastructure in order to maintain the assets that they have and construct new ones. Furthermore, infrastructure assets only have a finite capacity, so companies must construct new infrastructure if they wish to grow or expand. This limits the growth of most infrastructure companies when compared to something like a software company that only needs to duplicate a series of ones and zeros whenever a customer makes a purchase. Due to this limited growth, two other things are frequently true about infrastructure companies:

They have lower earnings multiples than more rapidly growing companies. This tends to result in much more attractive valuations than other sectors. The companies pay out a reasonably large proportion of their cash flows to their investors as dividends in order to provide an investment return in the absence of strong capital gains.

These two factors result in many midstream companies having considerably higher dividend yields than many other things in the market. We can see evidence of this simply by looking at the current yields of the largest holdings in BKGI’s portfolio. This table provides that information:

Company Name

% of Total Assets

Current Dividend Yield

Enel SpA (OTCPK:ENLAY)

8.96%

5.15%

Enbridge

8.51%

5.75%

Fortum Oyj (OTCPK:FOJCF)

8.32%

4.53%

Dominion Energy (D)

6.35%

4.49%

Omega Healthcare Investors (OHI)

5.60%

6.72%

Orange (OTC:ORANY)

5.29%

5.42%

Engie SA (OTCPK:ENGIY)

4.74%

7.14%

Italgas S.p.A. (OTCPK:ITGGF)

4.13%

4.23%

Bouygues SA (OTCPK:BOUYY)

4.08%

4.98%

Pennon Group plc (OTCPK:PEGRF)

3.55%

5.59%

As expected, we can certainly see some very high-yielding stocks in this list, including two that currently boast yields in excess of 6%. All of these companies have yields that are substantially higher than the 1.07% yield of the SPDR® S&P 500 ETF Trust (SPY), which is a popular way for investors to try and match the performance of the S&P 500 Index in their own portfolios. The current yields of many of these companies also add some support to the fund website’s statement that BKGI is trying to achieve an overall distribution yield of 6%; after all, many of the companies shown above have yields that come very close to that level.

The BNY Mellon Global Infrastructure Income ETF is an actively managed fund, whereas many of the other exchange-traded infrastructure funds in the market are passively managed. For example, the iShares Global Infrastructure ETF (IGF) simply tracks the S&P Global Infrastructure Index. This is the same index that is also tracked by the SPDR S&P Global Infrastructure ETF (GII), which explains why both of those funds have nearly identical performance over the past ten years:

The yields of these two funds are lower than that of the BNY Mellon Global Infrastructure Income ETF, however, as their yields are hovering around 3%. This could be important due to the fact that a significant portion of the total returns of infrastructure companies comes from the dividends that these companies pay out. They are somewhat like fixed-income securities in this respect. As such, we could expect the higher-yielding BKGI to outperform IGF and GII when measured on a total return basis over time. This has, in fact, been the case over the past three years, as BKGI has delivered a 79.38% total return, which has beaten both of the two global infrastructure exchange-traded index funds:

Unfortunately, the BNY Mellon Global Infrastructure Income ETF only has an inception date of November 2, 2022, so we cannot look at its performance prior to three years ago. However, this has been a remarkable performance for an infrastructure fund since inception, as it has not only managed to beat both of the index funds, but it even came somewhat close to matching the 84.10% total return of the S&P 500 Total Return Index (SP500TR). As infrastructure companies have underperformed the S&P 500 Index for most of the past fifteen years, this has been a rather impressive performance.

As the name of the fund suggests, the BNY Mellon Global Infrastructure Income ETF is a global fund that invests in infrastructure companies that are located in the United States as well as other countries. A look at the largest positions currently held in this fund would have left someone with a similar impression, as the fund does have a number of foreign names among its largest positions. However, it actually has more American exposure than might be thought, as the fund currently has 42.51% of its assets invested in American companies:

This actually represents a slight overweight to the United States when compared to the S&P Global Infrastructure Index (the index has a 40.93% weighting to the United States). However, apart from the United States being the largest country weighting in both BKGI and the index, the two are very different as far as their composition. Take a look at this comparison chart:

Country

Weight in BKGI

Weight in S&P Global Infrastructure Index

United States

42.51%

40.93%

France

19.49%

6.00%

Italy

12.18%

2.89%

Finland

7.00%

n/a

United Kingdom

6.66%

2.27%

Canada

4.70%

7.81%

China

1.65%

4.61%

Spain

1.27%

8.78%

Belgium

1.20%

n/a

We can immediately see that BKGI’s country weightings are vastly different from those of the index. Furthermore, the fund is more concentrated in only a few names than is the index, which is not really surprising for an actively managed fund. The second largest country weighting in the index is Australia, which at 8.87% is lower than all three of the top countries by weighting in the fund’s portfolio. It is quite likely that the fund has its weightings set up in this way in order to increase the yields that it earns from its assets.

It is also possible that the fund’s management expects Europe to outperform Australia overall, which has been the case over the past year. We can see this simply by looking at the performance of the MSCI Europe Index (IEUR) against the MSCI Australia Index (EWA) over the past year:

As is clearly shown, European equities have been outperforming Australian ones over the past year. It is therefore reasonable for the fund to invest more heavily in European Union countries than in Australia in pursuit of total return.

The Case For Infrastructure Right Now

Regular readers are likely aware that I have been concerned about a resurgence of inflation, which is one reason why I have been recommending against investing in most fixed-income funds. For example, in this article, I outright stated that the Federal Reserve appears to be abandoning its 2% inflation mandate, given that it is actually cutting when the data shows that inflation has been rising. We can see that here:

This chart shows the year-over-year rate of increase in the Consumer Price Index for All Urban Consumers. In both September and October 2025, the Federal Reserve cut interest rates even though the most recent inflation figures showed worse inflation than in the prior month. Furthermore, the central bank also cut interest rates back in November and December 2024, even though the most recent inflation data during both of those months was also coming in worse than during the previous months. If the central bank is willing to cut in such an environment, it suggests that it is no longer determined to get inflation down and investors should adjust their portfolios accordingly. This suggests that they should favor equities issued by companies that have a high degree of pricing power or have some other form of protection that allows them to raise prices in an inflationary environment.

Infrastructure companies, in general, do have such protection. For example, we already saw that over half of BKGI’s portfolio is invested in utilities. The majority of utilities enjoy monopoly status and provide a product that most people consider to be a necessity, which would give them a lot of pricing power in isolation. This is the reason why they are regulated fairly heavily by governments, as politicians do not want them to exploit that monopoly status in order to extract “excessive profits” from their customers.

Government regulators quite frequently limit or control the prices that utilities can charge. These same regulators do, however, want utilities to be profitable as it creates other problems if they are unprofitable or if they are unable to provide their owners with a reasonable return. Thus, these regulators ordinarily will allow a utility company to raise its prices alongside inflation. Midstream energy companies also inherently have some protection against inflation, as the contracts that they have with their customers include clauses that result in their revenues rising with inflation.

Another advantage that infrastructure stocks have during periods of high inflation is that their very high yields result in them having shorter durations than stocks issued by non-dividend-paying companies. In short, the cash flows provided by the stocks will allow the investor to recoup their initial investment more rapidly than would be the case with a company that won’t pay a dividend for years (or decades) into the future. All else being equal, the more rapidly the investor can get their money back, the less time that inflation has to compound against them.

Admittedly, some readers may point out that the capital gains from low-yielding high-growth stocks can also provide a return that allows the investor to recoup their initial investment, it is necessary to sell the stock in order to actually spend those capital gains. Short-duration assets are historically the way to go when inflation gets bad, and this overall provides a case for holding infrastructure stocks or other short-duration assets.

BKGI Expense Ratio

The BNY Mellon Global Infrastructure Income ETF has an expense ratio of 0.65%, but the fund sponsor has been reimbursing some of these expenses:

According to the fund’s website:

BNY Mellon ETF Investment Adviser, LLC has contractually agreed, until at least February 28, 2026, to assume the direct expenses at the fund so that the fund’s total annual operating expenses do not exceed 0.55% of the fund’s average daily net assets.

Thus, until the end of next February, the fund’s expense ratio will remain at 0.55%. It is possible that the expenses will increase after that date if the contractual agreement is not renewed.

Conclusion

In conclusion, the BNY Mellon Global Infrastructure Income ETF is an interesting actively managed exchange-traded fund that aims to provide a higher yield and higher total return than the comparable index ETFs that have been available on the market for a long time. Historically, it has done pretty well at this, as it has beaten the S&P Global Infrastructure Index since its inception.

However, the fund’s documentation claims to be attempting to get a 6% yield, and it is not currently paying that much. It is, however, paying a higher yield than the infrastructure indices, and when combined with its outperformance against them, could make it a pretty decent holding for anyone who is looking to generate income today.

data.title: GOVT: Still A Buy, But For Different Reasons
data.description:
The iShares U.S. Treasury Bond ETF (GOVT), launched on 02/14/2012 by BlackRock, Inc. and managed by BlackRock Fund Advisors, offers exposure to the entire U.S. Treasury curve, targeting Treasuries with 1-30-year maturities. It charges an expense ratio of 0.05% and manages about $33 billion.

Broad exposure to the Treasury market, as represented by GOVT, implies an intermediate-duration bias, which at this point is warranted. I initiated coverage of this ETF back in January, and I explained why it was a buy. I approached its attractiveness from a "yield sustainability" perspective. In this article, I am approaching it from the perspective of interest rate changes, as GOVT positions an investor to gain more from the upcoming rate cuts relative to other Treasury ETFs on a risk-adjusted basis.

Portfolio & Performance

The ETF is currently holding 212 Treasury securities, which are clustered around Treasury Notes that have intermediate-term maturities.

GOVT's 30-day SEC yield is currently 3.81%, and its effective duration is 5.76 years. This profile helps explain its performance in the past, as its sensitivity to interest-rate changes is moderate relative to an ETF like the iShares 20+ Year Treasury Bond ETF (TLT), but meaningful to behave differently than short-duration vehicles.

When GOVT was launched, yields were close to record lows as a result of the central bank's quantitative easing that followed the GFC. That's the reason that since inception and up to around 2018, the performance is insignificant; yields rose slowly from very low levels, so income power remained weak while rising rates acted as a driver of modest downward pressure on the fund's price.

Fast forward to 2020, when the Fed lowered the Fed Funds rate to practically 0% in order to bring stability to the markets and the economy; GOVT rose sharply due to the steep decline in yields.

After inflation rose to high levels in the following years, the Fed intervened again by aggressively raising the policy rate of interest. This was also steep enough for GOVT's price to tank in 2022.

Last, GOVT started recovering in late 2023 as it became clearer that inflation was falling towards the Fed's target and the central bank's rate hiking cycle was over.

In 2025, GOVT kept climbing higher in a consistent manner. TLT has outperformed it so far, but not consistently, highlighting the bumpy road of monetary policy fueled by new risks of inflationary pressure.

Opportunities & Risks

Speaking of which, inflation is one of the reasons that makes GOVT relatively attractive as opposed to long-duration vehicles. It remains sticky, as it started rising in late 2024 and resurfaced as a key issue during the summer. With CPI at 3%, meaningfully above the 2% target, the monetary policy path is tricky to forecast.

Compared with short-duration vehicles, however, GOVT appears to be more attractive as well. Along with a higher risk of inflation, the labor market is also at risk of becoming a serious issue due to its softening in 2025 so far. That biases the Fed towards cutting further, even though the timing is highly uncertain. In such a scenario, GOVT should outperform both short and long duration.

Growth is another tailwind for Treasuries. In the first half of 2025, GDP has grown by ~1.4% on an annualized basis as a result of a contraction in the first quarter and a recovery in the second. Tariffs must have played a role in that below-historical-average level of economic growth, on top of restrictive monetary policy over the last 3 years. Economic forecasters expect the trend to continue for some time. Although a recession is not the base case, the risk of one occurring is elevated, and along with soft growth, investors are likely to continue being defensive to a meaningful degree, favoring safe havens like Treasuries over equities.

There are, however, two main risks worth monitoring. The first is the scenario where inflation rises more dramatically in the near term than it has in the past 12 months. And second, fiscal policy implies that the budget deficit will remain wide; with the Fed not in QE mode, the issuance of intermediate-term Treasuries implies supply that the central bank will not be able to absorb, and this will apply upward pressure on yields.

Conclusion

This is not a time for a cash bias anymore, as rates are expected to come down faster now, and long duration offered by TLT offers a very early bet as the road will still be bumpy with inflation risk, as mentioned above. GOVT provides the sweet spot for fixed-income allocators.

Now, I am always open to challenging my views because being an ideologue in investing and trading can prove expensive. So if you have a different opinion, this platform is the right place to discuss both strategy and the various options with which we can position our portfolios. Go ahead and leave a comment below to let me know what you think.

Otherwise, please let me know if you found this article useful. It means a lot!

Thank you for reading.

data.title: Perimeter Solutions: Dilution Tamps Further Upside (Rating Downgrade)
data.description:
In my July article, I made the case that Perimeter Solutions, Inc. (PRM) was nearing a breakout. It did break out, and is now up ~54% since then. The core business is tracking my initial thesis around the fire safety business being less cyclical, and a bolt-on strategy mirroring TransDigm (TDG). On the other hand, the variable fees tied to advisory shares are set to rise alongside the stock’s performance. Given the dilutive effects of this arrangement, I think the risks and rewards are more or less in balance. I am, therefore, downgrading my rating to Hold.

Strong Quarter, Predictable Margins

Revenue in the Fire Safety segment (86% of total Q3 revenue) was up 9% to $273.4 million, despite a mild fire season in the U.S. I had covered the low correlation with fire activity before, so it wasn’t a big surprise. International retardant sales were a surprise. The 10-K does break up its international sales at 15%, but I had assumed they were mostly from the Specialty segment due to the Phosphorous Pentasulphide plant in Germany.

Management again didn’t share exact numbers, but they did mention that overseas sales were up about $5.5 million, adding roughly 2 percentage points to overall growth. Adjusted EBITDA margins expanded 200 basis points to 65% ($177.2 million), mainly due to the full-service model, which results in better cost absorption and a stickier customer base.

The Specialty Products segment was weaker by comparison. Revenue was up 15% to $42.1 million, but the segment’s adjusted EBITDA fell to $9.1 million from $12.9 million a year earlier. Management maintained ongoing problems and litigation with Flexsys, the plant operator, which may be prolonged and is likely to be a drag on performance.

Meanwhile, the IMS division continued to be a bright spot. It added four new product lines year-to-date and contributed $10.8 million of incremental revenue in Q3. The business is emerging as a scalable M&A platform that can absorb small industrial product lines and enhance them through Perimeter’s value-driver framework.

At a consolidated level, revenue rose 9% to $315.4 million, and adjusted EBITDA improved 9% to $186.3 million. Free cash flow came in at $193.6 million for the quarter, driven by seasonal working capital release. Overall, the quarter reinforced the thesis that Perimeter’s cash generation and margins are becoming structurally stronger and less dependent on the severity of any given fire season.

The USFS Contract

I looked up the old contract on USA spending, and it had obligated amounts of $264.7 million in 2024 and $309.7 million in 2025. Of the $574.9 million total, $409.4 million was spent. Now, 2024 was a record fire year, and 2025 was a milder season, and the total outlay averages to $205 million. The new contract averages to $224 million, given the ceiling of $1.1 billion over five years. I think the revenue from this contract will likely be lower than the ceiling amount. And it seems to me that the value of the contract lies in exclusivity that locks in Perimeter as the sole supplier and adds strength to its monopoly moat. It also provides flexibility to the USFS to expand prevention operations and provides the company a stable source of revenue over the next five years. The visibility is nice, but I prefer a conservative approach to re-rating this as a case for multiple expansion.

Rising Founder Fees And Dilution Risk

Based on the disclosure about the founder’s agreement, the fixed fee is 2.3 million shares per year, continuing through 2027. So, this represents a dilution of 1.55% on the 147.9 million shares outstanding. The variable fee, by contrast, depends on a few moving parts.

I calculated the average closing price for the 208 trading days this year, and it is $14.84. If I fill out the remaining trading days for the year at an average of $25, the projected average closing price would be $16.52. To follow the maths in the disclosure, we need to subtract the high watermark established when the variable fee was last made in 2021.

Increase ($2.89) = 2025 Average Price ($16.52) – Previous high watermark ($13.63).

The total variable fee in 2025 would be 18% of this increase multiplied by 157.1 million shares.

Fee per share = $2.89 x 18% = $0.5202.

Total potential 2025 variable fee = $0.5202 x 157,137,410 shares = $81,742,921.

Half of the distribution is required to be in stock, with the balance payable in cash or stock at the founders’ discretion. On its current market cap, the amount in its entirety represents a 2.6% dilution. I’d say this would still be fine, but the average closing price in 2025 was dragged down by lower levels earlier in the year. Let’s say the price on average is around $25 in 2026. In that scenario, the variable fee would climb to $239.8 million, or a 7.7% dilution on the current market cap.

Potential 2026 variable fee = (25 – 16.52) x 18% x 157,137,410 = $239,854,543.

If you consider the 4.65% dilution from the fixed fee (2025 – 2027), this nets to a 15% dilution without a potential variable fee in 2027 and a 0% return on the stock in 2026.

Valuation & Final Take

The valuation assumptions in my previous thesis turned out to be pretty conservative. The YTD adjusted EBITDA is already $295 million, whereas I had assumed about $312 million for the next twelve months. If you apply the YTD 20% growth rate to the final quarter, the run rate annualizes to $334 million. I have assumed about a 9% increase over that number for the next twelve months ($365 million). It’s based on the idea that even in a moderate fire year, the margin expansion from an all-powder footprint should offset the impact from the ongoing situation at the Sauget plant.

In the absence of dilution, I’d likely still maintain a Strong Buy rating and wait for more data in future earnings. But the dilution effects really tamp down the upside. A re-rating now depends more on some of the other catalysts, such as solid-state batteries, coming into play. I am therefore maintaining a hold rating for now.

data.title: VYMI: Foreign 4.3% Dividend Yield Made Cheap And Simple
data.description:
I often think of the Rockefeller quote "Do you know the only thing that gives me pleasure? It's seeing my dividends come in". What probably gives me even more pleasure is seeing my dividends come in from a variety of businesses around the world, operating in different countries, and paying me in different currencies. Good and solid dividend growth, in my view, is one of the better ways of building investment income that is protected from inflation, because even if the dollar weakens, these companies selling all over the world will convert their profits into whatever the market rate is to provide a growing level of purchasing power of all the things they are selling. For those who do not get as much pleasure from looking around the world for dividends, there are of course ETFs that make it easier than ever to buy a simple and cost effective package of these foreign dividend stocks, and collect their yields from a single ticker. The ETF I wanted to pick up and have a refreshed review of today is the Vanguard International High Dividend Yield Index ETF (VYMI).

I last reviewed VYMI in June 2023, when I compared it against Vanguard's other international dividend ETF that focuses more on dividend growth than high yield, the Vanguard International Dividend Appreciation ETF (VIGI). At that time, my conclusion was that I preferred VYMI over VIGI because of VYMI's significantly higher yield (=significantly deeper value tilt, and I believe in value), while still having enough of a screen on dividend growth. This quick chart shows how the total returns of the two funds have evolved since then.

Earlier in 2023, I also wrote what is still a very useful guide to what I believe are Vanguard's best ETFs to buy, though I find it worth mentioning here that VYMI and VIGI were not in that guide. That is because, in my view, these dividend focused ETFs are not "pure" to the original Vanguard idea of simply buying the total market at the lowest possible cost, as opposed to paying up for a dividend screened portfolio. That said, Vanguard still is a leader at doing even these strategies very well and at very low cost, so I still consider them to be a leader in this category.

In this update, I will focus on highlighting VYMI's current portfolio holdings, its prospects for continued dividend growth, and its main competitors. In conclusion, I will then explain who I think this ETF is for, and which type of account I believe it is best held in.

VYMI's Current Portfolio

Vanguard ETFs publish their holdings only quarterly, so these observations are based on what I see on VYMI's homepage dated September 30, 2025.

Geographically, VYMI is quite diversified with about 14% in Japan, 11% in the UK, 8% in Canada, 7% in Switzerland, and 7% in Australia, among the top 5 developed markets. Mainland Chinese stocks make up a little over 6% of VYMI, though Taiwan and Hong Kong respectively make up about another 4% and 2%, which adds up to an overall exposure of 12% to "Greater China", which also sounds about right. There are also +1% allocations to other interesting markets like India, Mexico, South Africa, Saudi Arabia, and Korea, so while I might want to see more of a tilt towards these more minor markets, at least some exposure is there.

In terms of sector exposure, the one big standout is that over 42% of VYMI is in financials. This may not be surprising given that in many foreign markets, financials are the largest, and in some cases, only dividend paying stock available in that market, and effectively act like a leveraged exposure to that country's credit market. While I would love to see international dividend ETFs separate financials and non-financials so I can do my own mix, for now, this is what we have. The next four largest sector weightings in VYMI are energy, industrials, consumer discretionary and consumer staples at about 7-8% each, so starting to look quite well balanced once we get past the financials.

As of this writing, the single largest reported holding is British-based and Hong Kong focused bank HSBC Holdings Plc (HSBC), which I first covered in 2017, and still hold some shares in today in a few client accounts. The next three holdings are Switzerland's top 3 giants Novartis (NVS), Roche (OTCQX:RHHBY), and Nestle (OTCPK:NSRGY), so even the #3 and #4 holdings in this ETF trade OTC on the US market, which is one reason many US investors might prefer them packaged in an ETF. Rounding out the top 10 are names most readers will be very familiar with: Shell, Toyota, Mitsubishi, RBC, CBA, and Allianz.

VYMI's Dividend: Past and Future

VYMI's reported dividend yield was 4.28% as of September 30, and would likely be about the same today as VYMI is up less than 1% over the month of October. That's only about 0.2% per year higher than the 10-year US Treasury yield (US10Y), so besides tax reasons (mentioned at the conclusion), the main reason to prefer VYMI over bonds is if you expect these dividends will not only not get cut, but will likely increase in the future. Below is the sum of dividends paid each calendar year since the fund's launch in 2016, showing an overall solid growth trend, even with plenty of fluctuation from year to year, much of which is due to currency fluctuations. Given the percentage of the portfolio invested in businesses that are likely to increase their dividends with inflation, I overall see this as a better long-term income portfolio than the 10-year treasury for many portfolios.

Year Sum of Dividend
2016 1.356
2017 2.1484
2018 2.4154
2019 2.6807
2020 1.9585
2021 2.8868
2022 2.8024
2023 3.0473
2024 3.2859
2025 (Q1-Q3) 2.3766

VYMI versus other International Dividend ETFs

VYMI is the largest non-US focused dividend ETF I am aware of at almost $13 billion in assets under management, over double that of the next largest with $6 billion, and the next three with about $2 billion each. Below is a quick YChart of these other four competing ETFs's relative assets under management, and rolling 5-year total returns, which I leave here with no further comment, as comparing these would deserve a whole different article. What I will mention here is that VYMI's expense ratio of only 0.17% is significantly lower than IDV's 0.49% and IHDG's 0.58%, but almost double the 0.09% charged by HDEF and DIVI. Of these two cheaper ETFs, HDEF focuses more on higher dividend yields, so its dividend yield is significantly higher than that of DIVI and closer to that of VYMI.

Conclusion

While VYMI is not the cheapest ETF focused on non-US high dividend stocks, it is the largest and overall has a solid portfolio, track record, and brand name. As with every ETF though, it's not for everyone, so I wanted to conclude by saying who it's for, where it's best to own it, and who it's not for.

VYMI could serve as a solid pillar in a portfolio primarily focused on generating dividend income, especially one that needs that dividend income to come from non-US sources to diversify away from US equity risk. In my view, it is ideally held in a US taxable account, as there it might be possible to claim foreign tax credits back from the foreign countries that withhold taxes on dividends paid out through this fund. I say more about foreign tax credits in this article, where I even say how to go even further with the idea for those who are really into maximizing foreign tax credits.

So who is VYMI not for? First of all, I think this ETF may not be the best buy for many non-US investors, as the US may withhold taxes on VYMI distributions over and above those already withheld by the foreign companies when sending their dividends to this fund. Second, I'd rather hold VYMI in a taxable account, and hold US dividend stocks in an IRA or tax sheltered account, in order to maximize the tax credit benefit, as mentioned already. Finally, I would also say VYMI is not for investors who don't need the income and instead want to maximise total return, as opposed to just income return. There is a whole other argument about dividends and total return, but for now, I hope this review has been helpful for those just wanting to see how well VYMI does its job of letting you see your dividends come in from dozens of countries around the world.

Editor's Note: This article discusses one or more securities that do not trade on a major U.S. exchange. Please be aware of the risks associated with these stocks.
